metadata.title: Hourly to Salary & Employer Cost Calculator
metadata.description: Convert an hourly wage to equivalent annual salary and related measures (including overtime, employer costs, and estimated take-home pay). Designed for clarity, auditability, and configurable assumptions.

standard_full_time.label: Standard full-time annual salary
standard_full_time.description: Calculates annual salary assuming all hours are paid at the base hourly rate with no overtime or additional employer costs.

with_overtime.label: Annual salary including overtime
with_overtime.description: Includes regular hours plus weekly overtime (paid at a multiplier). Useful for employees who work consistent overtime each week.

employer_total_cost.label: Employer total annual cost (salary + benefits + payroll taxes)
employer_total_cost.description: Estimates the employer's total cash cost by adding employer-paid benefits and payroll taxes to gross pay. Benefits and payroll tax percents are configurable assumptions.

take_home_estimate.label: Estimated employee take-home pay
take_home_estimate.description: Simple estimate of after-tax pay using a single income tax rate assumption. This is NOT a tax filing calculator; use local tax tables for precision.

fields.label: Pay periods per year (for per-paycheck estimates)

introduction: This tool converts an hourly wage into an equivalent annual salary and provides related measures such as employer total cost and estimated take-home pay. It uses configurable assumptions for hours, overtime, benefits, payroll taxes, and income tax to reflect different employment scenarios.

Use the fields to match your situation: enter your hourly rate, typical weekly hours, any consistent overtime, and the percentages you expect for employer-paid benefits and taxes. The calculator gives transparent intermediate values so you can audit assumptions.
methodology: Calculations are deterministic arithmetic based on user inputs. The tool separates regular pay, overtime pay, employer-paid benefits, payroll taxes, and a simple single-rate income tax to produce gross and net estimates.

This calculator is intended for planning and estimation. It does not replace payroll software or official tax calculators. For employer compliance, payroll withholding, and labor classification consult relevant federal and local regulations and your payroll provider.
how_is_calculated: Annual regular pay = hourly_rate × hours_per_week × weeks_per_year
Annual overtime pay = hourly_rate × overtime_hours_per_week × overtime_multiplier × weeks_per_year
Total annual gross pay = annual regular pay + annual overtime pay
Employer benefits cost = total annual gross pay × (benefits_percent / 100)
Employer payroll taxes = total annual gross pay × (payroll_taxes_percent / 100)
Employer total cost = total annual gross pay + benefits cost + payroll taxes
Estimated income tax (single-rate) = total annual gross pay × (income_tax_percent / 100)
Estimated take-home pay = total annual gross pay − estimated income tax
examples: Example 2: $30/hour, 40 regular hours + 5 overtime hours at 1.5×, benefits 20%, payroll taxes 8% → Gross = regular + overtime; Employer cost adds benefits and payroll taxes on top of gross.

faqs.question: Should I use 52 or 50 weeks per year?
faqs.answer: Use 52 weeks if you work year-round. Reduce the weeks per year if you expect unpaid leave or seasonal work. The weeks_per_year field is configurable to match real hours worked.

faqs.question: Does this calculate exact tax withholding?
faqs.answer: No. The take-home estimate uses a single user-specified income tax percentage and does not model progressive tax brackets, deductions, Social Security, Medicare, or state/local withholding. Use official tax calculators or payroll services for precise withholding.

faqs.question: How should I set employer benefits percent?
faqs.answer: Employer benefits percent should capture the employer's annual cost for health insurance, retirement contributions, paid leave, and other benefits as a share of salary. If unsure, common estimates range from 15% to 30% depending on benefit offerings.

faqs.question: Is overtime automatically included?
faqs.answer: Only if you provide an overtime_hours_per_week value or adjust the overtime_multiplier. If overtime_hours_per_week is zero, the calculation assumes no overtime.

faqs.question: Can this be used for classification of salaried vs hourly workers?
faqs.answer: This tool provides pay-equivalence estimates only. Legal classification depends on labor law tests and duties, not pay conversion. Consult labor regulations and legal counsel for classification decisions.

glossary.definition: Payment amount earned per hour of work, before taxes and deductions.
Annualized pay computed by multiplying hourly rate by hours worked per week and weeks worked per year; does not account for taxes or benefits unless specified.
Factor by which hourly pay increases for overtime hours (commonly 1.5 for time-and-a-half).
Estimated employer cash outlay including gross pay, employer-paid benefits, and employer payroll taxes.
Estimated income remaining after a simplified single-rate tax deduction; not a substitute for official withholding calculations.
